inlineContent.text: CPU-based 2D particle node used to create a variety of particle systems and effects.
, which provides the same functionality with hardware acceleration, but may not run on older devices.
This object emits the following signals:

abstract.text: Number of particles emitted in one emission cycle.
Particle system starts as if it had already run for this many seconds.
Maximum initial rotation applied to each particle, in degrees.
A 2D game object, inherited by all 2D-related nodes. Has a position, rotation, scale, and Z index.
Maximum initial angular velocity (rotation speed) applied to each particle in
Each particle’s initial color will vary along this
Maximum tangential acceleration applied to each particle. Tangential acceleration is perpendicular to the particle’s velocity giving the particles a swirling motion.
Each particle’s angular velocity will vary along this
Amount of time each particle will exist.
, results in fractional delta calculation which has a smoother particles display effect.
A color represented in RGBA format.
Each particle’s radial acceleration will vary along this
Unit vector specifying the particles’ emission direction.
Each particle’s rotation will be animated along this
Each particle’s orbital velocity will vary along this
The maximum rate at which particles lose velocity. For example value of
means that the particle will go from
Each particle’s hue will vary along this
Each particle’s vertical scale will vary along this

Types that conform to VariantRepresentable can be stored directly in
with no conversion.  These include all of the Variant types from Godot (for
SwiftGodot.Object) as well as the built-in Swift types UInt8, Int64 and Double.

The particle system’s frame rate is fixed to a value. For example, changing the value to 2 will make the particles render at 2 frames per second. Note this does not slow down the simulation of the particle system itself.
Maximum orbital velocity applied to each particle. Makes the particles circle around origin. Specified in number of full rotations around origin per second.
Each particle’s horizontal scale will vary along this

Each particle’s animation offset will vary along this
Particle system’s running speed scaling ratio. A value of
can be used to pause the particles.
Align Y axis of particle with the direction of its velocity.
How rapidly particles in an emission cycle are emitted. If greater than
, there will be a gap in emissions before the next cycle begins.
Maximum initial velocity magnitude for each particle. Direction comes from
Maximum radial acceleration applied to each particle. Makes particle accelerate away from the origin or towards it if negative.
Each particle’s color will vary along this
, particles use the parent node’s coordinate space (known as local coordinates). This will cause particles to move and rotate along the
node (and its parents) when it is moved or rotated. If
, particles use global coordinates; they will not move or rotate along the
node (and its parents) when it is moved or rotated.
Maximum animation offset that corresponds to frame index in the texture.
Each particle’s scale will vary along this
Framework to write Godot Game Extensions using the Swift Programming Language.
Sets the direction the particles will be emitted in when using .directedPoints.
Maximum initial scale applied to each particle.
Particles will be emitted inside this region. See

Sets the initial positions to spawn particles when using .points or .directedPoints.
Maximum initial hue variation applied to each particle. It will shift the particle color’s hue.
Emitted when all active particles have finished processing. When
is disabled, particles will process continuously, so this is never emitted.
can be used to start and stop particles from emitting. However, if
will not restart the emission cycle until after all active particles finish processing. You can use the [signal finished] signal to be notified once all active particles finish processing.
